# Draft:Saint Edward Catholic School

St. Edward Catholic School is a private school located in Corona, California, and is part of the Roman Catholic Diocese of San Bernardino. It is recognized as the oldest private school in the city of Corona. The school serves approximately 270 students from preschool through eighth grade. It is accredited by the Western Catholic Educational Association (WCEA) and the Western Association of Schools and Colleges (WASC).
History
St. Edward Catholic School was founded in 1947 by the Sisters of St. Francis and Monsignor Thompson. At the time, it operated under the Roman Catholic Diocese of San Diego, which included Riverside County. The school is located just south of the parish church at 500 S Merrill Street. The initial school building contained four classrooms. A second building, known as Building B, was constructed in 1962.
In 1978, the newly formed Diocese of San Bernardino took jurisdiction over the school. Until 1994, the faculty included members of the Religious Sisters of St. Francis of Philadelphia.
In 2024, alumni Yvonne Molnar was named principal of the school.
Campus and Programs
The school campus includes two main academic buildings, a chapel, a library, and a student play area. A SmartLab was recently added, which includes a video production studio and technology workspace.
St. Edward School offers a variety of extracurricular programs including student council, sports, and a studio production club. It also participates in the Diocese of San Bernardino's academic decathlon and placed second in 2025. The schoolâ€™s VEX Robotics team placed second overall at the VEX Rapid Relay event held at St. George Catholic School. The school also hosts annual Christmas programs.
The school was also a participant in the University of Notre Dame's Trustey STEM Teaching Fellows program, reflecting its investment in integrated STEM education.
